segment.source: Understanding AppLocker default rules (Windows 10)
segment.target: Understanding AppLocker default rules (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professional describes the set of rules that can be used to ensure that required Windows system files are allowed to run when the policy is applied.
segment.target: This topic for IT professional describes the set of rules that can be used to ensure that required Windows system files are allowed to run when the policy is applied.

segment.source: Understanding AppLocker default rules
segment.target: Understanding AppLocker default rules

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professional describes the set of rules that can be used to ensure that required Windows system files are allowed to run when the policy is applied.
segment.target: This topic for IT professional describes the set of rules that can be used to ensure that required Windows system files are allowed to run when the policy is applied.

segment.source: AppLocker includes default rules for each rule collection.
segment.target: AppLocker includes default rules for each rule collection.

segment.source: These rules are intended to help ensure that the files that are required for Windows to operate properly are allowed in an AppLocker rule collection.
segment.target: These rules are intended to help ensure that the files that are required for Windows to operate properly are allowed in an AppLocker rule collection.

segment.source: Important: You can use the default rules as a template when creating your own rules.
segment.target: Important: You can use the default rules as a template when creating your own rules.

segment.source: However, these rules are only meant to function as a starter policy when you are first testing AppLocker rules so that the system files in the Windows folders will be allowed to run.
segment.target: However, these rules are only meant to function as a starter policy when you are first testing AppLocker rules so that the system files in the Windows folders will be allowed to run.

segment.source: If you require additional app security, you might need to modify the rules created from the built-in default rule collection.
segment.target: If you require additional app security, you might need to modify the rules created from the built-in default rule collection.

segment.source: For example, the default rule to allow all users to run .exe files in the Windows folder is based on a path condition that allows all files within the Windows folder to run.
segment.target: For example, the default rule to allow all users to run .exe files in the Windows folder is based on a path condition that allows all files within the Windows folder to run.

segment.source: The Windows folder contains a Temp subfolder to which the Users group is given the following permissions:
segment.target: The Windows folder contains a Temp subfolder to which the Users group is given the following permissions:

segment.source: Traverse Folder/Execute File
segment.target: Traverse Folder/Execute File

segment.source: Create Files/Write Data
segment.target: Create Files/Write Data

segment.source: Create Folders/Append Data
segment.target: Create Folders/Append Data

segment.source: These permissions settings are applied to this folder for app compatibility.
segment.target: These permissions settings are applied to this folder for app compatibility.

segment.source: However, because any user can create files in this location, allowing applications to be run from this location might conflict with your organization's security policy.
segment.target: However, because any user can create files in this location, allowing applications to be run from this location might conflict with your organization's security policy.
